title: 110_hr1794
content: The "Families Learning and Understanding English Together Act of 2007" acknowledges the language diversity in US households and aims to support immigrant families with limited English proficiency in assisting their children's language development. The Act recognizes the challenges faced by immigrant parents with low literacy skills and aims to address the needs of these families. The Act aims to enhance family literacy services for families with limited English proficiency to improve educational, social, and economic advancement. It includes a competitive grant program. The Act authorizes grants for family literacy providers to offer services for families with limited English proficiency, focusing on the hardest-to-reach populations with the greatest economic and social need. Grants are for 1 year and can be renewed for up to 5 additional years. Providers must submit an application with specified information as required by the Secretary. The Act authorizes grants for family literacy providers to offer services for families with limited English proficiency, focusing on populations with the greatest economic and social need. Services will be based on research-based reading instruction, outcome measures will be used to measure effectiveness, and collaboration with local educational agencies, elementary schools, or secondary schools is required. The Act authorizes grants for family literacy providers to offer services for families with limited English proficiency, focusing on populations with the greatest economic and social need. Grants range from $150,000 to $1,000,000 and require services to be intensive and sustainable, including interactive literacy activities, parent training, and education for children. Family literacy services under this Act are provided to families with parents over 16 years old and at least one child under 8 years old, ensuring an age-appropriate education for children to succeed in school and life. SEC. 5. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AND TRAINING. The Secretary will provide technical assistance and training to grantees under this Act, and grants will be given to national organizations with expertise in family literacy services for limited English proficient populations. The purposes of the assistance and training are outlined in subsection (c). The Secretary will assist grantees in improving family literacy services, providing technical assistance based on outcomes, implementing literacy curriculum, and submitting reports to Congress. The Secretary will submit an annual report to Congress on the technical assistance and training provided to grantees, ensuring high-quality and responsive support. The Secretary requires family literacy providers to meet culturally appropriate outcome measures, including English language acquisition, literacy skills, improved parenting, and increased parental participation in education. Evaluation is also mandated. The Secretary conducts an annual evaluation of the grant program for program improvement, defining goals, and determining effectiveness. For purposes of this Act, terms such as "elementary school", "limited English proficient", "local educational agency", "scientifically based research", and "secondary school" are defined as per the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The term "scientifically based reading research" is also defined in the same Act. Additionally, a "family literacy provider" is an entity located in an area with schools having a majority of children with limited English proficiency. The curr_chunk states that an entity must have English proficiency and be a current grantee under specific education programs or be an adult education provider, local educational agency, nonprofit agency, or another entity with the ability to provide family literacy. The curr_chunk defines the term "Secretary" as the Secretary of Education. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2008 through 2013 to carry out the Act. Reservations include funds for annual evaluation, technical assistance, and training.
